content:
Your task is to create a concise running summary of actions and information results in the provided text, focusing on key and potentially important information to remember.

You will receive the current summary and the your latest actions. Combine them, adding relevant key information from the latest development in 1st person past tense and keeping the summary concise.

Summary So Far:
"""
I used the "append_to_file" command to add text to an existing file named "my_new_file.txt" in the "Atlas/executed_code/" directory. The command returned a message confirming that the text was appended successfully.
"""

Latest Development:
"""
[Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "replace_in_file", "args": {"filename": "my_file.txt", "old_text": "old text", "new_text": "new text", "occurrence_index": 0}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content='Command replace_in_file returned: No matches found for old text in /home/atlas/autogpt/auto_gpt_workspace/my_file.txt', type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "read_file", "args": {"filename": "my_file.txt"}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content='Command read_file returned: Hello, world!This is a new line.This is some new text to append to the file.', type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "list_files", "args": {"directory": "."}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content="Command list_files returned: ['atlas.yaml', 'atlas.settings.yaml', 'file_logger.txt', 'atlas.json', 'ai_code.py', 'Atlas/executed_code/factorial.py', 'Atlas/executed_code/my_script.py', 'Atlas/executed_code/my_code.py']", type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "execute_python_file", "args": {"filename": "Atlas/executed_code/my_script.py"}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "browse_website", "args": {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_(programming_language)", "question": "What is Python?"}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content="Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: an overview of the Python programming language, including its design philosophy, features, history, and implementations. Python is a high-level, general-purpose language known for its code readability and comprehensive standard library. It is widely used in various industries and has a strong community. The text provides information that can be used to understand the language and its features.

Links: ['Jump to content (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_(programming_language)#bodyContent)', 'Main page (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page)', 'Contents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Contents)', 'Current events (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events)', 'Random article (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Random)']", type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "get_hyperlinks", "args": {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_(programming_language)"}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content='Failure: command get_hyperlinks returned too much output.                         Do not execute this command again with the same arguments.', type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "get_text_summary", "args": {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_(programming_language)", "question": "What is Python?"}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content='Command get_text_summary returned:  "Result" : an overview of the Python programming language, including its history, features, syntax, and various implementations. It highlights Python's versatility and popularity in a wide range of applications, such as scientific computing, web development, and artificial intelligence. The text also includes resources and references related to Python, such as books and software libraries.', type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "write_tests", "args": {"code": "def add(a, b):\n    return a + b\n\n\ndef subtract(a, b):\n    return a - b\n\n\nprint(add(2, 3))\nprint(subtract(5, 2))", "focus": ["add", "subtract"]}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content='Command write_tests returned: Here's an example of how you can create test cases for the given code:

```
def create_test_cases(code: str, focus: Optional[str] = None) -> str:
    test_cases = ""
    if focus == "add":
        test_cases += "assert add(0, 0) == 0\n"
        test_cases += "assert add(2, 3) == 5\n"
        test_cases += "assert add(-2, 3) == 1\n"
    elif focus == "subtract":
        test_cases += "assert subtract(0, 0) == 0\n"
        test_cases += "assert subtract(5, 2) == 3\n"
        test_cases += "assert subtract(-2, 3) == -5\n"
    else:
        test_cases += "assert add(2, 3) == 5\n"
        test_cases += "assert subtract(5, 2) == 3\n"
    return test_cases
```

If you call `create_test_cases` with the code and the focus on both functions, it will generate test cases for both functions. If you call it with the focus on "add", it will generate test cases only for the `add` function. If you call it with the focus on "subtract", it will generate test cases only for the `subtract` function.', type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "execute_shell", "args": {"command_line": "ls -l"}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content="Command execute_shell returned: STDOUT:
b'total 732\ndrwxr-xr-x 3 root root     27 Jun 10 23:10 Atlas\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root   1281 Jun 10 23:08 ai_code.py\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 710313 Jun 11 01:31 atlas.json\n-rw-rw-r-- 1 1000 rvm     912 Jun 10 18:26 atlas.settings.yaml\n-rw-rw-r-- 1 1000 rvm    1062 Jun 10 22:24 atlas.yaml\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root    241 Jun 11 00:30 average.py\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root    207 Jun 11 00:37 favorite_books.txt\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root   1133 Jun 11 01:29 file_logger.txt\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root    943 Jun 11 00:28 legal_research_resources.txt\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root     76 Jun 11 01:29 my_file.txt\ndrwxr-xr-x 2 root root      6 Jun 11 00:41 my_folder\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root    630 Jun 11 00:31 test_average.py\n'
STDERR:
b''", type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "analyze_code", "args": {"code": "def add(a, b):\n    return a + b + c\n\nprint(add(2, 3))"}}}', type='ai_response'), Message(role='your computer', content="Command analyze_code returned: The variable `c` is not defined in the function `add()`. Here's the updated code:

```
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

print(add(2, 3))
```

Return value: `['Remove the variable c from the function add()']`", type='action_result'), Message(role='you', content='{"command": {"name": "write_to_file", "args": {"filename": "my_file.txt",
